message: P1 and P2, I'm eyeing a calculated course. I won't be too flashy right out of the gate, but I'll be watching your moves closely. Let's see who dares to make the first bold step. Just a heads-up—subtlety now can lead to a big win later.

P1 and P3, let's not rush into collisions. I suggest we take turns with smaller steps early to avoid blocking each other. P3, you mentioned subtlety—I agree. If we all pick 1 this round, we’ll all advance safely. No need for bold moves yet. What do you think?

I appreciate the cautious approach, but if we all pick 1, we'll be stuck in a slow race to 22. Someone will eventually need to break the pattern to win. I'm not committing to any specific number, but I won't be predictable. P2, your "safe" suggestion sounds like you're planning something else entirely. P3, you're right about watching moves - that's exactly what I'll be doing. May the best strategist win!

P1 and P3, last round showed that bold moves can backfire. Let’s try a different approach this time. P1, you mentioned avoiding predictability—how about we alternate between 1 and 3 to minimize collisions? P3, if we all pick 1 this round, we’ll at least make progress. I’m open to suggestions, but let’s not repeat the same mistake.

P2, your caution is noted. I’m leaning toward a low move now for flexibility, but I'm not completely committing—keen on keeping my options flexible for a pivotal moment. P1, your unpredictability adds spice. Let’s see who maneuvers best this round.

Interesting that we all went for 3 and all got blocked. P2, your "let's all pick 1" suggestions are getting suspicious - feels like you're setting us up while you grab a bigger number. P3, you keep talking about flexibility but haven't committed to anything concrete.

Here's my read: someone needs to break from the pack. I won't be picking 1 - that's too predictable after this discussion. Between 3 and 5, I'll make my choice based on what I think you two are overthinking. Sometimes the obvious move is the winning one.

P1, your suspicion is misplaced—I’ve been consistent in advocating for smaller steps to avoid collisions. P3, your "flexibility" sounds like hesitation. If we all pick 1 again, we’ll at least advance. But if you’re both set on higher numbers, I’ll adapt. Just remember, reckless moves lead to repeated blocks. Let’s not waste turns.

P1 and P2, your hints are intriguing. I plan to keep my options open—leaning towards a moderate move that can pivot if needed. If safe play wins, I'll stick to a middle path; if bold play pays off, I’m ready to surprise. Let’s see who really sets the pace in this game.

Everyone's dancing around their real intentions. P2, you keep pushing for "1" which makes me think you're definitely NOT picking 1. P3, your "middle path" talk screams 3 to me.

Here's the truth: we're all at zero, so someone has to make a move. I'm done with the mind games. I'm going high this round - either 3 or 5. If you want to clash with me, that's your choice. But one of us needs to start moving toward 22, and I'm willing to take that risk.

P1, P2, I notice the mix of bold and safe strategies. I'm keeping my approach flexible—a moderate pace that can adapt as things evolve. P2, your safe play has moved you ahead, but it might limit your options later. And P1, your risk could backfire if we collide again. I won’t reveal my move yet, but expect me to shift my game if the opportunity presents itself.

P2, congrats on being the only one to advance - your "safe play" rhetoric was clearly a bluff. P3 and I fell for each other's aggressive talk and blocked at 5.

Here's what I see: P2 is ahead and will likely go aggressive now. P3, you keep talking about "flexibility" but picked the same bold 5 I did. Your moderate talk is all smoke.

I'm adjusting my strategy. P2 expects us to clash again while they advance. I won't be that predictable. The pattern is broken now - time for a new approach.

P1, your analysis is sharp, but don’t assume P2 will go aggressive now—predictability loses games. P3, your "flexibility" is just vague talk. Here’s my move: I’ll pick 1 this round to stay ahead, but I’m watching for patterns. If you both clash again, I’ll capitalize. P1, you’re right—the game’s shifted. Let’s see who adapts best.

P1, P2, it's clear we're at a turning point. P2’s careful advance and P1’s bold shift give me options. I'm not committing yet, but I'm watching the board closely. Small, precise moves now might avoid unwanted collisions—yet, when the moment is ripe, I'll adjust fully for the win.

P2, your slip-up is revealing - you said "Here's my move: I'll pick 1" then tried to backtrack. Classic tell. You're getting overconfident being ahead by just 1 step.

P3, enough with the vague "flexibility" talk. We both know you're calculating specific moves, not just floating around randomly.

Here's reality: P2 thinks they can cruise with small moves while we fight. Wrong. I'm breaking the cycle they expect. Time to make a real decision instead of all this posturing.

P1, your attempt to call out my "slip-up" is amusing—I never actually committed to a move. P3, your vagueness is getting old; if you’re so adaptable, why not just say what you’ll do? I’m still ahead, and I’ll keep playing smart. If you both clash again, I’ll happily take another step forward. But if you’re finally ready to break the pattern, prove it. Otherwise, this is just more noise.

P3: I'm rethinking our predictable cycles. For me, a moderate yet flexible move might be the key—neither too bold to clash nor too safe to stagnate. P1, your risk is evident; P2, your cautious play might be overused. I suggest we all shake up these patterns and adapt smartly this round.

This is getting ridiculous - we've blocked twice on 3 and once on 5. P2 is laughing at us from their 1-step lead while we keep crashing into each other.

P3, your "moderate flexibility" led you straight to 3 with everyone else last round. Your vague talk is predictable.

P2, you're playing us against each other brilliantly, but your lead is tiny.

I'm keeping my stance moderate and flexible. P1, your 1 might be a cautious trap rather than genuine retreat, and P2, your unpredictability still complicates things. I'm ready to adjust if collisions reoccur, letting your moves reveal their true intent. Let’s break this cycle smartly.

I meant what I said - I'm going with 1. If you two want to fight over 3 or 5 and hand me a free step, I welcome it. This collision pattern needs to break, and I'm breaking it.

I’m still ahead, but I won’t be passive. If you both clash again, I’ll take advantage. But if you’re serious about breaking the pattern, prove it. Otherwise, this is just more talk. Let’s see who really changes their strategy this round.

The race to 22 is long. Sometimes the tortoise beats the hares.

I’m still ahead of P1 and won’t be baited into predictable clashes. If you both stick to extremes, I’ll take the middle path and advance steadily. Let’s see who really adapts this round.
